before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"7o8ks","text":"Breeding and Rearing of Zebrafish","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8kr8u","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ntos","text":"Timing: 4 days","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aju7m","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ae69g","text":"This section describes the method for breeding and rearing the zebrafish larvae in preparation for the light/dark behavioral assay. 5 days prior to running the larval behavioral assay the adult zebrafish (6-12 months) should be prepared for breeding. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2fl4o","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7p5jl","text":"Breeding is performed through the addition of substrate (typically marbles) to the home tank and/or pair breeding. For marbling, the night before embryo collection place a container of marbles into the tank of adult fish. The following day, at 1100 - mid-day remove the container and collect the embryos (Figure 1A and B). For pair breeding, select either one male and one female, or two females and one male, or two males and one female and place into a small tank with a middle divider and a slope. Split the sexes the night before and the next morning remove the divider when the lights in the facility turn on and allow 30-mins for breeding before returning to their home tank and collecting the embryos (Figure 1C). ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":305,"length":15},{"style":"bold","offset":709,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9tdg7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16t56","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8jv36","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a0jnl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qtkf","text":"2. Transfer ~80 0 hour post-fertilization (hpf) embryos into labelled 250 mL Petri dishes, filled with system water (or the water you use in your lab) and place the dishes into a temperature controlled incubator with a standard 14h:10h light/dark cycle (Figure 1D). Each morning post breeding perform a complete water change of the Petri dishes and remove any dead/unfertilized larvae. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":254,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"faf05","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77rc8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"85di2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aq2pi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"272us","text":"Uploading Tracking Script to Behavioral Unit","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":44}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"60lfc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"916bf","text":"Timing: 5-mins","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f1qkf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdkja","text":"This section describes the setup and use of the zantiks (Zantiks Ltd., Cambridge, UK) automated tracking script for running the light/dark assay using MWP behavioural units. description: {"blocks":[{"key":"9dfek","text":"Zebrafish (Danio rerio) are a dynamic model organism, the larval stage (≤ 4 days post-fertilization (dpf)) of which offers a unique avenue for high-throughput in vivo investigation in a vertebrate that aligns strongly with the 3Rs of in vivo research. The light/dark locomotor assay is widely employed for studying larval behavior; however, there remains a lack of experimental consistency. Here, we provide step-by-step experimental and\nanalytical protocols for a standardized behavioral assay that exploits locomotion differences during light/dark phases. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":11,"length":11},{"style":"italic","offset":159,"length":8},{"style":"italic","offset":234,"length":7},{"style":"STRIKETHROUGH","offset":557,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ah80i","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5neh8","text":"For details on the use and execution of this protocol, please refer to Hillman (2024).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5ae65","text":"We perform a normalization of the data by calculating the percentage of movement per minute per fish to the overall baseline response. This step is essential to ensure reproducible and robust responses (Hillman et al., 2024). Tracking errors are common and are eliminated using a regularly used method for outlier identification and removal (median absolute deviation) (Leys et al., 2013).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f024q","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5917","text":"An important step in the statistical analysis is the calculation of observed power and sample size. We have provided a flow chart for how to deal with 4 dpf larval behavior sample size and power analyses (Figure 6). A preliminary behavioral experiment must be conducted with a sample size of n = 16 per concentration. The R script can be run and observed power calculated for dark phase responses. Where power is below 0.8 (80%), sample size is calculated. If the observed power is above or equal to 0.8 (80%) then the sample size can remain as n =16.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":205,"length":8},{"style":"italic","offset":292,"length":6},{"style":"italic","offset":545,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d5ef","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7skdc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"uhp5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d2vo1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e06ka","text":"The first analysis performed is a linear mixed model (LMM) analysis with movement as the dependent variable and lights as the independent variable with fish ID as the random effect.
